affiliation.orgName: School of Public Policy and Management

analytic.title: International Journal of Approximate Reasoning

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Non-additive probability Strong law of large numbers Independence Upper expectation Bernoulli experiment

div.p: In this paper, with the notion of independence for random variables under upper expectations, we derive a strong law of large numbers for non-additive probabilities. This result is a natural extension of the classical Kolmogorov's strong law of large numbers to the case where the probability is no longer additive. As an application of our result, we give most frequent interpretation for Bernoulli-type experiments with ambiguity.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The classical strong laws of large numbers as fundamental limit theorems in probability theory play an important role in the development of probability theory and its applications. The key in the proofs of these limit theorems is the additivity of probabilities and expectations. However, such additivity assumption is not reasonable in many areas of applications because many uncertain phenomena can not be well modeled using additive probabilities or additive expectations. More specifically, motivated by some problems in mathematical economics, statistics, quantum mechanics and finance, a number of papers have used non-additive/imprecise probabilities or nonlinear expectations (for example Choquet integral/expectation, g-expectation) to describe and interpret the phenomena (see for example [1,3,4,[9][10][11]14,15,20,[22][23][24]).

Recently, motivated by the risk measures, super-hedge pricing and modeling uncertainty in finance, Peng [16][17][18][19] initiated the notion of independent and identically distributed (IID for short) random variables under sub-linear expectations. Under this framework, he proved a law of large numbers for sub-linear expectations. In this paper, we are interested in the strong law of large numbers (SLLN for short) for non-additive probabilities, we develop new approaches to solve this problem. We obtain a new SLLN for non-additive probabilities. It is a natural extension of the classical Kolmogorov's SLLN, but the proofs here are different from the original proofs of the classical SLLN. Now we describe the problem in more details. For a given set P of probability measures on ( , F), we define a pair (V, v) of non-additive probabilities by The corresponding Choquet integrals/expecations (C V , C v ) are defined by
where V is replaced by V and v respectively.
The pair of so-called upper-lower expectations (E, E) with respect to P is defined by
div.formula: E[X] := sup P∈P E P [X], E[X] := inf P∈P E P [X].
div.p: Here and in the sequel, E P denotes the classical expectation under probability P.
In general, the relation between Choquet integrals and upper-lower expectations is as follows: for any random variable X,
div.formula: C v [X] ≤ E[X], E[X] ≤ C V [X].(1)
div.p: Note that under some very special assumptions on P and V, both inequalities could become equalities (see for example [10,11,20]).

Given a sequence {X i } ∞ i=1 of IID random variables for non-additive probabilities, the earlier papers related to strong laws of large numbers are Dow and Werlang [6] and Walley and Fine [23]. However, the more general results for strong laws of large numbers for non-additive probabilities were given by Cooman and Miranda [3], Epstein and Schneider [7], Maccheroni and Marinacci [12] and Marinacci [13]. They show that, on full set, any cluster point of empirical averages lies between the lower Choquet integral C v [X 1 ] and the upper Choquet integral C V [X 1 ] with probability one under non-additive probability
div.formula: v. That is v ⎛ ⎝ ω ∈ : C v [X 1 ] ≤ lim inf n→∞ 1 n n i=1 X i (ω) ≤ lim sup n→∞ 1 n n i=1 X i (ω) ≤ C V [X 1 ] ⎞ ⎠ = 1.
div.p: Maccheroni and Marinacci [12] and Marinacci [13] obtain their result under the assumptions that v is a totally monotone capacity on a Polish space , and random variables {X i } ∞ i=1 are bounded or continuous. Epstein and Schneider [7] also show the same result under the assumption that V is rectangular. Cooman and Miranda [3] show another SLLN similar to the above result under the assumption that v is 2-monotone. Comparing with the classical SLLN for probabilities, the above extra assumptions for SLLN for non-additive probabilities seem too strong.
Moreover, because of the inequalities in (1), the gap between the Choquet integrals C
div.formula: V [X 1 ] and C v [X 1 ] is bigger than that of the upper-lower expectations E[X 1 ] and E[X 1 ] for all X 1 ,
div.p: it is of interest to ask whether we can obtain a more precise result if the Choquet integrals/expctations in the above equality are replaced by upper-lower expectations under some weaker assumptions on v and random variables
div.formula: {X i } ∞ i=1 . That is v ⎛ ⎝ ω ∈ : E[X 1 ] ≤ lim inf n→∞ 1 n n i=1 X i (ω) ≤ lim sup n→∞ 1 n n i=1 X i (ω) ≤ E[X 1 ] ⎞ ⎠ = 1.
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to show that the above equality is still true under some weaker assumptions. As a corollary (see Corollary 3.2), we obtain a Strassen-type invariance principle (cf. [21]) of SLLN for non-additive probabilities.

This paper is a extension version of [2]. The remainder is organized as follows. In Section 2, we recall some basic concepts and related lemmas which will be useful in this paper. In Section 3, we state and prove the main result of this paper, that is the SLLN for non-additive probabilities. Section 4 gives an application of the SLLN to Bernoulli-type experiments with ambiguity.

div.head: Basic concepts and lemmas
div.p: Let ( , F) be a measurable space, and M be the set of all probability measures on . Every non-empty subset P ⊆ M defines an upper probability
div.formula: V(A) := sup P∈P P(A), A ∈ F,
div.p: and a lower probability
div.formula: v(A) := inf P∈P P(A), A ∈ F.
div.p: Obviously V(•) and v(•) are conjugate to each other, that is

where A c is the complement set of A. Definition 2.1. V (•) is a set function from F to [0, 1], V (•) is called a non-additive probability if it satisfies the following properties (i)(ii) and is called a lower or an upper continuous non-additive probability if it further satisfies the following property (iii) or (iv):
div.formula: (i) V (φ) = 0, V ( ) = 1. (ii) V (A) ≤ V (B), whenever A ⊂ B and A, B ∈ F. (iii) V (A n ) ↑ V (A), if A n ↑ A, where A n , A ∈ F. (iv) V (A n ) ↓ V (A), if A n ↓ A, where A n , A ∈ F.

div.head: Lemma 2.1. V(•) is a lower continuous non-additive probability and v(•) is an upper continuous non-additive probability. And V(•) being upper/lower continuous is equivalent to v(•) being lower/upper continuous.
div.p: Proof. From the definition of V(•) and v(•), it is obvious that both V(•) and v(•) satisfy properties (i) and (ii). It is easy to check that V(•) being upper/lower continuous is equivalent to v(•) being lower/upper continuous, since V(•) and v(•) are conjugate to each other. So we just need to show that V(
div.formula: •) is lower continuous. For A n , A ∈ F, A n ↑ A, then A = ∞ n=1 A n , therefore V(A) = sup P∈P P(A) = sup P∈P lim n→∞ P(A n ) ≤ lim n→∞ sup P∈P P(A n ) = lim n→∞ V(A n ).
div.p: On the other hand, by the monotonicity of V(•), we have
div.formula: V(A) ≥ lim n→∞ V(A n ). Therefore, V(A) = lim n→∞ V(A n ).
div.p: The proof is complete.
div.formula: Definition 2.2. Let {A n } ∞ n=1 be a sequence of events in F, {A n } ∞
div.p: n=1 is said to be mutually independent with respect to non-additive probability
div.formula: V (•), if for any i ∈ N * , V ⎛ ⎝ ∞ n=i A n ⎞ ⎠ = ∞ n=i V (A n ). A sequence of random variables {X n } ∞ n=1 is said to be mutually independent with respect to V (•), if for any {A n } ∞ n=1 ⊆ F, any i ∈ N * , we have V ⎛ ⎝ ∞ n=i (X n ∈ A n ) ⎞ ⎠ = ∞ n=i V (X n ∈ A n ).
div.p: Definition 2.3 (Quasi-surely, Definition 3 in [5]). A set D is polar set if V(D) = 0 and a property holds "quasi-surely" (q.s. for short) if it holds outside a polar set.

div.head: Now we define the upper expectation E[•] and the lower expectation E[•]
div.p: on ( , F) generated by P, for each F measurable real random variable X such that E P [X] exists for each P ∈ P,
div.formula: E[X] := sup P∈P E P [X], E[X] := inf P∈P E P [X].
div.p: ( , F, P, E) is called an upper expectation space and ( , F, P, E) is called a lower expectation space.
It is easy to check that E
div.formula: [X] = -E[-X] and E[•] is a sub-linear expectation (more details can see [16-19]) on ( , F), in other words, E[•] satisfies the following properties (a)-(d): for all F measurable real random variables X, Y , (a) Monotonicity: X ≥ Y implies E[X] ≥ E[Y]. (b) Constant preserving: E[c] = c, ∀c ∈ R. (c) Positive homogeneity: E[λX] = λE[X], ∀λ ≥ 0. (d) Sub-additivity: E[X + Y ] ≤ E[X] + E[Y].
div.p: By properties (b) and (d), it is easy to check that E[•] satisfies translation invariance, that is, for any constant c, E[X + c] = E[X] + c. Moreover, every sub-linear expectation has a representation of upper expectation (see [19] for more information).

Hölder inequality, Chebyshev inequality and Jensen inequality are the basic inequalities of classical probability theory. Now we give their forms in upper expectation space. Proposition 2.1. Let X, Y be real measurable random variables on upper expectation space ( , F, P, E).
(1) Hölder inequality. For p, q > 1 with
div.formula: 1 p + 1 q = 1, we have E|XY| ≤ (E|X| p ) 1 p (E|X| q ) 1 q .
div.p: (2) Chebyshev inequalities. Let f (x) > 0 be a nondecreasing function on R. Then for any x,
div.formula: V(X ≥ x) ≤ E[f (X)] f (x) , v(X ≥ x) ≤ E[f (X)] f (x) .
div.p: Let f (x) > 0 be a even function on R and nondecreasing on (0, ∞). Then for any x > 0,
div.formula: V(|X| ≥ x) ≤ E[f (X)] f (x) , v(|X| ≥ x) ≤ E[f (X)] f (x) . (3) Jensen inequality. Let f (•) be a convex function on R. Suppose that E[X] and E[f (X)] exist. Then E[f (X)] ≥ f (E[X]).

div.head: Proof
div.p: (1) It follows from the classical Hölder inequality that
div.formula: E|XY| = sup P∈P E P |XY| ≤ sup P∈P (E P |X| p ) 1 p (E P |X| q ) 1 q ≤ sup P∈P (E P |X| p ) 1 p sup P∈P (E P |X| q ) 1 q = (E|X| p ) 1 p (E|X| q ) 1 q .
div.p: (2) Chebyshev inequalities can be deduced from the classical Chebyshev inequalities in the similar way as using in (1). We omit the details.
(3) For any λ < 0, it follows from the positive homogeneity of
div.formula: E[•] and E[X] ≥ E[X] = -E[-X] that E[λX] = λ -E[-X] ≥ -λ -E[X] = λE[X].
div.p: Hence for any λ ∈ R, we have
div.formula: E[λX] ≥ λE[X].
div.p: For any convex function f : R → R, there exists a countable set D in R 2 such that
div.formula: f (x) = sup (λ,μ)∈D (λx + μ).
div.p: By the translation invariance of E[•], we have
div.formula: E[f (X)] = E sup (λ,μ)∈D (λX + μ) ≥ sup (λ,μ)∈D E[λX + μ)] ≥ sup (λ,μ)∈D (λE[X] + μ) = f (E[X]).
div.p: We complete the proof of Proposition 2.1.
Now we give the definition of independence on upper expectation space ( , F, P, E).
Definition 2.4 (Independence). Let X 1 , X 2 , . . . , X n+1 be real measurable random variables on ( , F). X n+1 is said to be independent of (X 1 , . . . ,
div.formula: X n ) under E[•], if for each nonnegative measurable function ϕ i (•) on R with E[ϕ i (X i )] < ∞, i = 1, . . . , n + 1, we have E ⎡ ⎣ n+1 i=1 ϕ i (X i ) ⎤ ⎦ = E ⎡ ⎣ n i=1 ϕ i (X i ) ⎤ ⎦ E[ϕ n+1 (X n+1 )].
div.p: {X n } ∞ n=1 is said to be a sequence of independent random variables, if X n+1 is independent of (X 1 , . . . , X n ) for each n ∈ N * .

Remark 2.1. Peng initiated the notion of independent and identically distributed random variables under sub-linear expectations (see for example [16][17][18][19]). However, the notion of independence in this paper is weaker than Peng's definition.
The following proposition shows the relation between the above independence and pairwise independence in Maccheroni and Marinacci [12].
div.formula: Proposition 2.2. Let {X n } ∞
div.p: n=1 be a sequence of independent random variables on upper expectation space ( ,
div.formula: F, P, E), then {X n } ∞ n=1 is also pairwise independent with respect to V, that is, for each n > m ≥ 1 and for all G n , G m ∈ B(R), V(X n ∈ G n , X m ∈ G m ) = V(X n ∈ G n )V(X m ∈ G m ).
div.p: Proof. For i = 1, . . . , n, we choose
div.formula: ϕ i (x) = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ I G i (x), i = n, m; 1, otherwise.
div.p: Then by the definition of independence, it is easy to obtain
div.formula: V(X n ∈ G n , X m ∈ G m ) = V(X n ∈ G n )V(X m ∈ G m ).
div.p: The proof is complete.
div.formula: E e αX+βY = E e αX • E e βY .
div.p: By Jensen inequality, we have for α, β ∈ R + ,
div.formula: E e αX+βY ≥ e αE[X] • e βE[Y] . Example 2.2. If X is independent of Y under E[•], then (-X) is independent of (-Y), X + a is independent of Y + b, and XI {|X|≤c} is independent of YI {|Y|≤d} under E[•], for any a, b ∈ R, c, d ∈ R + .
div.p: Borel-Cantelli Lemma is one of the most fundamental theorems in classical probability theory. Next we show that Borel-Cantelli Lemma is still true for non-additive probabilities under some assumptions. Lemma 2.2 (Borel-Cantelli lemma). Let {A n } ∞ n=1 be a sequence of events in F and (V, v) be a pair of upper and lower probability generated by P.
div.formula: If ∞ n=1 V(A n ) < ∞, then V ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A i = 0.
div.p: (2) If further v(•) is lower continuous and {A c n } ∞ n=1 are mutually independent with respect to v(•), that is, for any
div.formula: n ∈ N * , v ⎛ ⎝ ∞ i=n A c i ⎞ ⎠ = ∞ i=n v(A c i ). Also if ∞ n=1 V(A n ) = ∞, then V ⎛ ⎝ ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A i ⎞ ⎠ = 1. Proof (1) 0 ≤ V( ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A i ) ≤ V( ∞ i=n A i ) ≤ ∞ i=n V(A i ) → 0, as n → ∞.
div.p: The proof of the first Borel-Cantelli Lemma is complete.
(2) For v(•) being lower continuous, we get that V(•) is upper continuous, hence
div.formula: 0 ≤ 1 -V ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A i = 1 -lim n→∞ V ∞ i=n A i = lim n→∞ 1 -V ∞ i=n A i = lim n→∞ v ∞ i=n A c i = lim n→∞ ∞ i=n v(A c i ) = lim n→∞ ∞ i=n (1 -V(A i )) ≤ lim n→∞ ∞ i=n exp(-V(A i )) = lim n→∞ exp - ∞ i=n V(A i ) = 0.
div.p: . We complete the proof of the second Borel-Cantelli Lemma.

div.head: The strong law of large numbers for non-additive probabilities
div.p: Before we introduce the main result, let us first prove the following lemma.
div.formula: Lemma 3.1. Given upper expectation E[•], let {X i } ∞ i=1 be a sequence of independent random variables such that sup i≥1 E [|X i | 1+α ] < ∞ for some constant α > 0. Suppose that there exists a constant c > 0 such that |X n -E[X n ]| ≤ cn ln(1 + n)
div.p: Then for any m > 1 we have
div.formula: sup n≥1 E ⎡ ⎣ exp ⎛ ⎝ m ln(1 + n) n n i=1 [X i -E[X i ]] ⎞ ⎠ ⎤ ⎦ < ∞. Proof. Firstly, if for α > 1, sup i≥1 E[|X i | 1+α ] < ∞, by Jensen inequality, we have sup i≥1 E[|X i | 1+β ] < ∞ for all 0 < β ≤ 1. So,
div.p: we just consider the case 0 < α ≤ 1.
It is easy to prove that sup
div.formula: i≥1 E[|X i | 1+α ] < ∞ implies sup i≥1 E[|X i |] < ∞ and sup i≥1 E[|X i -E[X i ]| 1+α ] < ∞. Noticing that lim n→∞ n α [ln(1+n)] 1+α = ∞, thus, for any m > 1 there exists a constant n m ∈ N * such that n α [ln(1 + n)] 1+α ≥ m 1+α , ∀n ≥ n m .
div.p: That is
div.formula: m ln(1 + n) n 1+α ≤ 1 n , ∀n ≥ n m .
div.p: On the other hand, it can be directly verified that the following inequality holds:
For any given
div.formula: n ≥ n m , i ∈ N * , i ≤ n, set x = m ln(1+n) n [X i -E[X i ]
div.p: ] and put it to (3). Then we obtain that exp
div.formula: m ln(1 + n) n [X i -E[X i ]] ≤ 1 + m ln(1 + n) n [X i -E[X i ]] + m ln(1 + n) n 1+α |X i -E[X i ]| 1+α exp 2m ln(1 + n) n |X i -E[X i ]| .
div.p: By assumption, it is easy to check that
div.formula: m ln(1 + n) n |X i -E[X i ]| ≤ m ln(1 + i) i |X i -E[X i ]| ≤ cm.
div.p: Together with (2), we have exp
div.formula: m ln(1 + n) n [X i -E[X i ]] ≤ 1 + m ln(1 + n) n [X i -E[X i ]] + |X i -E[X i ]| 1+α n e 2cm .
div.p: Taking E[•] on both sides of the above inequality and setting
div.formula: L := sup i≥1 E[|X i -E[X ]| 1+α ],
div.p: we have
div.formula: E exp m ln(1 + n) n [X i -E[X i ]] ≤ 1 + L n e 2cm . By the independence of {X i } ∞ i=1 , E exp m ln(1+n) n n i=1 [X i -E[X i ]] = n i=1 E exp m ln(1+n) n [X i -E[X i ]] ≤ 1 + L n e 2cm n → e Le 2cm < ∞, as n → ∞.
div.p: The proof is complete.
The following theorem is the main result of this paper. It gives a strong law of large numbers for non-additive probabilities.

div.head: Theorem 3.1 (SLLN).
div.p: Let {X i } ∞ i=1 be a sequence of independent random variables for upper expectation E
div.formula: [•]. Suppose sup i≥1 E[|X i | 1+α ] < ∞ for some α > 0, and E[X i ] ≡ μ, E[X i ] ≡ μ. Set S n := n i=1 X i . Then V {lim inf n→∞ S n /n < μ} {lim sup n→∞ S n /n > μ} = 0, (4) and v μ ≤ lim inf n→∞ S n /n ≤ lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≤ μ = 1.
div.p: Proof. Since V(•) and v(•) are conjugate to each other, ( 5) is equivalent to (4). And using the monotonicity and sub-additivity of V(•), it is easy to check that the argument ( 4) is equivalent to the conjunction of
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ S n /n > μ = 0, (6) and V lim inf n→∞ S n /n < μ = 0. (7)
div.p: Next we prove (6) in two steps.
Step 1. Assume that there exists a constant c > 0 such that |X n -μ| ≤ cn ln(1+n) for n ≥ 1. Then, {X i } ∞ i=1 satisfy the assumptions of Lemma 3.1.
To prove (6), we first show that for any > 0,
Let us choose m > 1/ , by Lemma 3.1, we have
div.formula: sup n≥1 E ⎡ ⎣ exp ⎛ ⎝ m ln(1 + n) n n k=1 (X k -μ]) ⎞ ⎠ ⎤ ⎦ < ∞. By Chebyshev inequality, V(S n /n ≥ μ + ) = V( S n -nμ n ≥ ) = V m ln(1+n) n n k=1 (X k -μ) ≥ m ln(1 + n) ≤ e -m ln(1+n) E exp m ln(1+n) n n k=1 (X k -μ) ≤ 1 (1+n) m sup n≥1 E exp m ln(1+n) n n k=1 (X k -μ) . Since m > 1 and sup n≥1 E exp m ln(1+n) n n k=1 (X k -μ) < ∞, following from the convergence of ∞ n=1 1 (1+n) m , we have ∞ n=1 V(S n /n ≥ μ + ) < ∞.
div.p: By the first Borel-Cantelli Lemma, (8) holds, then
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≥ μ + = 0.
div.p: From Lemma 2.1, V(•) is lower continuous, therefore (6) holds, that is
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ S n /n > μ = 0, then v lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≤ μ = 1.
div.p: Step 2. Let {X i } ∞ i=1 only satisfy the assumptions of Theorem 3.1. For any fixed c > 0, set
div.formula: X n := (X n -μ)I |X n -μ|≤ cn ln(1+n) -E (X n -μ)I |X n -μ|≤ cn ln(1+n) + μ.
div.p: Immediately,
div.formula: X n = X n + (X n -μ)I |X n -μ|> cn ln(1+n) + E (X n -μ)I |X n -μ|≤ cn ln(1+n)
div.p: , and for each n ∈ N * , E[X n ] ≡ μ, and also
div.formula: |X n -μ| ≤ 2cn ln(1 + n) .
div.p: Meanwhile, for each n ≥ 1, it is easy to check that
div.formula: |X n -μ| ≤ |X n -μ| + E[|X n -μ|].
div.p: Then by Jensen inequality, we have
div.formula: E[|X n -μ| 1+α ] ≤ 2 1+α E[|X n -μ| 1+α ] + (E[|X n -μ|]) 1+α ≤ 2 2+α E[|X n -μ| 1+α ] < ∞, since sup i≥1 E[|X i | 1+α ] < ∞. Then {X i } ∞
div.p: i=1 satisfies the assumptions of Lemma 3.1.
div.formula: Set S n := n i=1 X i , then, 1 n S n = 1 n S n + 1 n n i=1 (X i -μ)I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) + 1 n n i=1 E (X i -μ)I |X i -μ|≤ ci ln(1+i)
div.p: the subadditivity and translation invariance of E[•], we have
div.formula: E (X i -μ)I |X i -μ|≤ ci ln(1+i) = E (X i -μ) + (μ -X i )I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) ≤ E[X i ] -μ + E (μ -X i )I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) ≤ E |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i)
div.p: Therefore,
div.formula: 1 n S n ≤ 1 n S n + 1 n n i=1 |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) + 1 n n i=1 E |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) . (9)
div.p: Applying the Hölder and Chebyshev inequality, we have
div.formula: ∞ i=1 E |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) i ≤ ∞ i=1 1 i (E[|X i -μ| 1+α ]) 1/(1+α) E I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) α/(1+α) ≤ ∞ i=1 [ln(1 + i)] α c α i 1+α E[|X i -μ| 1+α ] ≤ sup i≥1 E[|X i -μ| 1+α ] 1 c α ∞ i=1 [ln(1 + i)] α i 1+α < ∞. By Kronecker Lemma, lim n→∞ 1 n n i=1 E |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) = 0. (10
div.p: Next we want to show
div.formula: lim n→∞ 1 n n i=1 |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i)
div.p: = 0, q.s.. (11) Similarly by the Kronecker Lemma, we only need to prove that
div.formula: ∞ i=1 |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) i < ∞, q.s.. Set A i := {|X i -μ| > ci ln(1+i) } for i ≥ 1. By Chebyshev inequality, V(A i ) = V |X i -μ| > ci ln(1 + i) ≤ ln(1 + i) ci 1+α E[|X i -μ| 1+α ],
div.p: then,
div.formula: ∞ i=1 V(A i ) ≤ sup i≥1 E[|X i -μ| 1+α ] ∞ i=1 ln(1 + i) ci 1+α < ∞.
div.p: From the first Borel-Cantelli Lemma, we have V
div.formula: ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A i = 0, then v ⎛ ⎝ ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A c i ⎞ ⎠ = 1. For any ω ∈ ∞ n=1 ∞ i=n A c i , there exists n(ω) ∈ N * such that for i > n(ω), ω ∈ A c i , that is |X i -μ| ≤ ci ln(1+i) Therefore, quasi-surely, ∞ i=1 |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) i = ⎛ ⎝ n(ω) i=1 + ∞ i=n(ω)+1 ⎞ ⎠ |X i -μ|I |X i -μ|> ci ln(1+i) i < ∞.
div.p: Consequently, (11) holds.
Taking lim sup n→∞ on both sides of ( 9), due to (10)
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ S n /n > μ = 0.
div.p: Hence, (6) holds, that is
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ S n /n > μ = 0, then v lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≤ μ = 1.
div.p: Similarly, considering the sequence {-X i } ∞ i=1 , from E[-X i ] ≡ -μ, we obtain
div.formula: V lim sup n→∞ (-S n )/n > -μ = 0.
div.p: Hence, (7) holds, that is,
div.formula: V lim inf n→∞ S n /n < μ = 0, then v lim inf n→∞ S n /n ≥ μ = 1.
div.p: Therefore, the proof of Theorem 3.1 is complete.
If V or v is additive, that is P = {P}, then we have μ = μ, and in this case our SLLN reduces to a standard Kolmogorov limit law
div.formula: P lim n→∞ S n /n = E P [X 1 ] = 1.
div.p: Furthermore, we have the following corollary. On the other hand, if v lim n→∞ S n /n = a = 1, from Theorem 3.1, we have
div.formula: v μ ≤ lim inf n→∞ S n /n ≤ lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≤ μ = 1. Let A := ω : μ ≤ lim inf n→∞ S n (ω)/n ≤ lim sup n→∞ S n (ω)/n ≤ μ , B := ω : lim n→∞ S n (ω)/n = a . Then v(A ∩ B) = 1, since 1 ≥ v(A ∩ B) = 1 -V(A c ∪ B c ) ≥ 1 -V(A c ) -V(B c ) = 1. So a = μ = μ.
div.p: It is of interest that using our SLLN, it is easy to obtain a Strassen-type invariance principle (cf. [21]) of SLLN for non-additive probabilities.
Corollary 3.2. For any continuous function ϕ(•) on R, under the assumptions of Theorem 3.1, we have
div.formula: V ⎛ ⎝ lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) < inf u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ lim sup n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) > sup u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ⎫ ⎬ ⎭ ⎞ ⎠ = 0, and v ⎛ ⎝ inf u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ≤ lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) ≤ lim sup n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) ≤ sup u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ⎞ ⎠ = 1. Proof. Let A := ω : μ ≤ lim inf n→∞ S n (ω)/n ≤ lim sup n→∞ S n (ω)/n ≤ μ . That is A = ω : lim n→∞ inf m>n S m (ω)/m, lim n→∞ sup m>n S m (ω)/m ⊆ μ, μ .
div.p: Fixed ω ∈ A, for any > 0, there exist n (ω) ∈ N * such that for any n > n (ω)
div.formula: inf m>n S m (ω)/m, sup m>n S m (ω)/m ⊆ μ -, μ + . Hence, lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n (ω)/n) = lim n→∞ inf m>n ϕ(S m (ω)/m) = lim n→∞ inf u∈ inf m>n S m (ω)/m,sup m>n S m (ω)/m ϕ(u) ≥ inf u∈[μ-,μ+ ] ϕ(u)
div.p: It can be deduced from the arbitrariness of and the continuity of ϕ(
div.formula: •) that lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n (ω)/n) ≥ inf u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u). Similarly, lim sup n→∞ ϕ(S n (ω)/n) ≤ sup u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u). Then A ⊆ ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ ω : inf u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ≤ lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n (ω)/n) ≤ lim sup n→∞ ϕ(S n (ω)/n) ≤ sup u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ⎫ ⎬ ⎭ .
div.p: From Theorem 3.1 and monotonicity of v(•), we have
div.formula: v ⎛ ⎝ inf u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ≤ lim inf n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) ≤ lim sup n→∞ ϕ(S n /n) ≤ sup u∈[μ,μ] ϕ(u) ⎞ ⎠ = 1.
div.p: We complete the proof of Corollary 3.2.

div.head: Bernoulli-type experiments with ambiguity
div.p: In this section, we give an application of SLLN to Bernoulli-type experiments with ambiguity.

In classical probability theory, repeated independent experiments are called Bernoulli experiments if there are only two possible outcomes for each experiment and their probabilities remain the same throughout the experiments [8]. However, the following Ellsberg urn model with imprecise probabilities do not remain the same throughout the experiments.

Example 4.1. Considering a countable infinity urns, ordered and indexed by the set N * = {1, 2, . . .}. You are told that each urn contains 100 balls with either red or blue color, that is, i = {R, B}, moreover, the number of red balls in each urn is from 25 to 50. We do not know additional information about these urns. One ball will be drawn from each urn, which defines "experiment". Let define the random variable on i by
div.formula: Y i (ω i ) = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ 1, if ω i = R i.e
div.p: . the ball drawn from the ith urn is red; 0, if ω i = B i.e., the ball drawn from the ith urn is blue.

For the i-th urn, because we do not know the precise number of red balls, thus we do not know the precise distribution of random variable Y i . Indeed, in this case, probability measures depend on the number of red balls, let r be the possible number of red balls in each urn, thus the possible probability measures for each urn is a set of probability measures, say Denote F the product σ -algebra on . Define the set of probabilities P on measure space ( , F) by
(E, E) denote the upper-lower expectations generated by P while (V, v) denote the upper-lower probabilities generated by P. A random variables sequence {X i } ∞ i=1 on ( , F) is defined by
div.formula: X i (ω) = Y i (ω i ), ∀i ∈ N * .
div.p: It is easy to check that {X i } ∞ i=1 is a sequence of independent random variables in the sense of Definition 2.

figure.head: V
figure.figDesc: (A) := sup P∈P P(A), v(A) := inf P∈P P(A), ∀A ∈ F.

figure.head: Corollary 3 . 1 .
figure.figDesc: Under the assumptions of Theorem 3.1, v lim n→∞ S n /n = a = 1 holds if and only if a = μ = μ. Proof. If a = μ = μ, it is obvious v lim n→∞ S n /n = a = 1 from Theorem 3.1.

figure.head: P
figure.figDesc: i := {P r , r ∈ {25, . . . , 50}}. Define full state space = ∞ i=1 i = 1 × 2 × • • • .
4 while E[X i ] ≡ 1/2 and E[X i ] ≡ 1/4. Thus V {lim inf n→∞ S n /n < 1/4} {lim sup n→∞ S n /n > 1/2} = 0, and v 1/4 ≤ lim inf n→∞ S n /n ≤ lim sup n→∞ S n /n ≤ 1/2 = 1.
